Title: Object: The X Plagues of Egypt
Description: A satire on current events represented in a group of figures identified in a key below: I (in the centre), Britannia, weepig, “a Nation without a K[in]g"; 2 (to the left of her), Frederick, Prince of Wales, “A Je ne'sca Quoi” sitting on a lower seat without a wig although in state robes with a pantin (puppet) dangling from the collar of his order; 3 (further to the left) a “Dancing Instructor” elaborately dressed, holding a small fiddle in one hand and with his other placing three musical notes on the prince’s bare head; 4 (to the right of Britannia), a “A Modern G[enera]l”, the Duke of Cumberland, standing in profile holding out his general’s baton, his head represented only in lightly etched outline; 5, “A Metropolis Without Trade”, the figure of the City of London, sitting downcast on the bank of the Thames; 6, “Liberty destroy’d”, an even more downcast figure holding the cap of Liberty with chains attached to her wrists; 7, “A French Engineer”, Charles Labelye, the Swiss architect of Westminster Bridge, saying "Morbleu", standing on one of its collapsed piers lettered “L[abelye] Fec”, a heavy cannon on each shoulder and three more cannon (as used to stabliise the pier) at his feet; 8 (on the left), “Religion w[i]th deceit” a two-faced cleric; 9 (further to the left) “Law & no Justice” holding up a balance in which a bag of coins outweighs a book lettered “LAW”; 10 (behind the City) “Poverty”, a ragged man clasping his hands in despair. 1748 Etching and engraving
Producer name: Print made by: L (or possibley E) Gilbert
Curator's comments: Frederick, Prince of Wales, was unpopular in some quarters for his opposition to the government at a time when he was expected soon to succeed George II (then in his late sixites); he is mocked for his interest in music The City's loss of trade, and increased poverty, followed the War of Austrian Succession. This is an early example of the image of the cap of Liberty in a British context.
Bibliographic references: BM Satires / Catalogue of Political and Personal Satires in the Department of Prints and Drawings in the British Museum (3020)
Associated names: Representation of: Prince William Augustus, Duke of Cumberland
Representation of: Frederick, Prince of Wales
Associated places: Topographic representation of: City of Westminster (Bridge)
